passages.text: Neutral is not enough

A substantial drop in exports weighed on GDP growth in Q2, with a \(1.6\%\) decline in output overall. With modest revisions lower to Q1, tariffs and trade disruptions have resulted in essentially flat growth overall through the first half of the year. This will imply an even wider output gap in H1. We continue to expect weakness that so far concentrated in trade- exposed sectors will spread to the broader economy. And even without a further sharp contraction in activity, stagnant growth will imply the economy remains in excess supply. Neutral policy rates will not be enough to close the output gap. We continue to expect a rate cut in September and beyond to a policy rate of \(1.75\%\) . This may become more likely after next Friday's employment data, where we expect the unemployment rate to rise to \(7.2\%\) in August.

With data through the first half of the year at hand, the impact of tariffs and trade escalations with the US had the impact of keeping overall growth stagnant. While weakness is mainly in trade-exposed parts of the economy, and domestic demand still rose in H1, we continue to see elevated risks that this weakness will spread.

This would clearly concern BoC officials and likely prompt further cuts, but even flat growth keeps the economy in excess supply. Falling Q2 GDP and modest revisions lower to Q1 suggests a slightly wider output gap. We do not think neutral policy rates will be enough to close this gap. Officials may increasingly start discussing the possible need for slightly accommodative rates later this year. We continue to expect another rate cut in September and policy rates reaching 1.75% in coming quarters.
Figure 1.Markets pricing \(50\%\) probability of a cut in September
\(①\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research
Figure 2.Exports weighed substantially on Q2 GDP
\(①\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Statistics Canada

Comments from Governor Macklem this week failed to give any near- term guidance on monetary policy, focusing instead on the inflation- targeting framework ahead of next year's policy review. Unsurprisingly, Macklem reaffirmed commitment to the \(2\%\) inflation target, but did question what the best way to measure core inflation would be and highlighted that the BoC has used a variety of measures in the past.

Our main takeaway is that officials (rightfully so, in our view) increasingly see CPI- trim and CPI- median as currently out of line with fundamentals and overstating the degree of underlying inflation. We continue to think officials will modify or expand the definition of preferred core inflation measures in the review next year.

A sharp plunge in exports weighed substantially on Q2 GDP, which declined \(1.6\% \text{QoQ}\) SAAR, matching our expectations but weaker than consensus at \(- 0.7\%\) and slightly softer than the BoC's \(- 1.5\%\) estimate. Details showed rebounding domestic demand as expected but with slightly different details.

Consumption was strong, with a boost to goods spending from some front- loaded purchases such as autos. But services consumption was also strong, possibly reflecting increased demand for domestic discretionary services in favor of US

Flat growth through the first half of the year largely reflected weakness in trade- exposed sectors, particularly various goods industries. Goods output declined again in June GDP by industry, with a weaker than expected \(0.1\%\) decline in June GDP overall. Statistics Canada estimates that activity rose \(0.1\%\) in July.

But we expect activity to largely move sideways through the second half of the year as well (penicillin in \(0.2\%\) Q3 GDP and \(0.3\%\) Q4). This would reflect some broadening of weak activity to other parts of the economy. Weakness in services employment in July may be an early indication of that dynamic, but data over the coming months would need to confirm more broadly slowing growth.
Figure 3. Business investment was particularly weak in Q2
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Statistics Canada
Figure 4. Goods sectors exposed to trade have been soft
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Statistics Canada
Key events in Canadian markets next week
Thursday, September 4, 8:30am

After falling exports weighed substantially on GDP growth in Q2, trade patterns will remain an important driver of quarterly GDP figures this year, but also for the economy as a whole. Data like PMI export orders suggest that while exports are not declining substantially further, exports in July could remain low. We will also continue to watch details of trade data, such as exports of metals, over the coming months as tariffs from the US on these goods have increased.

While many USMCA- compliant goods are excluded from reciprocal tariffs, this reciprocal rate applied to \(\sim 5\%\) of exports did rise further in August from \(25\%\) to \(35\%\) . Steel and aluminum tariffs will also apply to Canadian goods with no USMCA exemption and rose to \(50\%\) in early June. The coverage of steel and aluminum tariffs also recently expanded to include more goods. As trade- exposed sectors remain weak and account for a substantial share of the Canadian economy, continued weakness in exports increases the risk of weaker activity broadening to the rest of the economy.
Figure 5. Exports could remain subdued in July
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Figure 6. Some sectors have experienced larger tariff increases
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research, Statistics Canada
Source: Citi Research, Statistics Canada

Net Change in Employment (Aug) - Citi: - 45k, median: 10k, prior: - 40.8k Unemployment Rate - Citi: 7.2%, median: 7.0%, prior: 6.9% Hourly Wage Rate Permanent Employees - Citi: 3.4%, median: 3.5%, prior: 3.5%

After a 41k decline in employment in July, we expect a similarly larger 45k decline in employment in August, essentially retracing the 83k increase in employment in June. Monthly changes in labor force survey can be particularly volatile and large swings from June through August could reflect difficulties with seasonal adjustment. But averaging through monthly employment figures this year would

still imply flat to falling employment overall. For most of this year, this weakness has been particularly concentrated in trade- exposed industries, such as various goods- producing sectors. But in July, weakness in employment was due to less trade exposed sectors, such as information, business services, and health care. If this trend continues in August, it could be a sign that weaker activity, which began due to trade issues, is starting to broaden to the rest of the economy.

A falling participation rate limited an increase in the unemployment rate in July, but we expect a combination of falling employment and stable participation in August will have the unemployment rate rising to \(7.2\%\) . Weaker overall job growth this year will partly be a reflection of slowing population growth, but flat or falling employment on average would still be weak enough to imply a rising unemployment rate. Wage growth was surprisingly strong in July, mainly due to a strong monthly increase as there has been some strength in July wages in the past. We expect wage pressures to ease further as the labor market weakens.
Figure 7. Average job growth has slowed close to flat this year
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Statistics Canada
Figure 8. More weakness in services employment could suggest softer demand is broadening
